facts.text: This appeal, by special leave, is directed against the judgment of the Judicial Commissioner, Himachal Pradesh affirming a decree of the Senior Sub-Judge, Mandi dismissing the appellants suit.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is directed against the judgment of the Judicial Commissioner, Himachal Pradesh affirming a decree of the Senior Sub-Judge, Mandi dismissing the appellants suit.

facts.text: There was a public auction on February 25, 1952 at Mandi in Himachal Pradesh for the grant of a monopoly vend-licence to sell by retail country-liquor for the year April 1, 1952 to March 31, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: There was a public auction on February 25, 1952 at Mandi in Himachal Pradesh for the grant of a monopoly vend-licence to sell by retail companyntry-liquor for the year April 1, 1952 to March 31, 1953.

facts.text: The appellant was the highest bidder for Rs. 1,28,600/- and his bid was accepted.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the highest bidder for Rs. 1,28,600/- and his bid was accepted.

facts.text: In accordance with the terms and conditions of the auction, 1/6 of the amount of the bid had to be deposited by him within a month. This sum amounting to Rs. 21,460/- was so deposited.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with the terms and companyditions of the auction, 1/6 of the amount of the bid had to be deposited by him within a month. This sum amounting to Rs. 21,460/- was so deposited.

facts.text: The appellant who had started working his licence made payments of the monthly instalments of Rs. 10,714/- each for the months of April and May.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who had started working his licence made payments of the monthly instalments of Rs. 10,714/- each for the months of April and May.

facts.text: Subsequently thereto there were disputes raised by the appellant that the Excise authorities had defaulted in performing certain of the obligations undertaken by them, in the matter of the supply of liquor etc.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently thereto there were disputed raised by the appellant that the Excise authorities had defaulted in performing certain of the obligations undertaken by them, in the matter of the supply of liquor etc.

facts.text: The appellant stopped his sales of liquor.

anchor.surface_text: with the result that he stopped his sales of liquor

facts.text: Appellant served a notice under section 80 of the Civil Procedure Code dated September 2, 1952 on Government making a claim for damages for alleged breach of certain of the stipulations.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter served a numberice under section 80 of the Civil Procedure Code dated September 2, 1952 on Government making a claim for damages for alleged breach of certain of the stipulations.

facts.text: After receipt of this notice the Collector of Excise directed the suspension of the appellants licence under section 36 of the Punjab Excise Act, 1914.

anchor.surface_text: After receipt of this numberice the Collector of Excise directed the suspension of the appellants licence under section 36 of the Punjab Excise Act, 1914

facts.text: Thereafter proceeded under section 39 of that Act to take over the management of the vend-shops which theretofore were under the management of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter proceeded under section 39 of that Act to take over the management of the vend-shops which theretofore were under the management of the appellant.

facts.text: As the appellant did not pay the monthly instalments due from and after June, 1952 the Collector also took steps for the recovery of these instalments.

anchor.surface_text: As the appellant did number pay the monthly instalments due from and after June, 1952 the Collector also took steps for the recovery of these instalments.

facts.text: The appellant then filed a suit No. 345 of 1952 on the file of the Sub-Judge of Mandi on November 26, 1952 along with certain others... for a permanent injunction restraining the State of Himachal Pradesh from realising the balance of the licence-fees due from him.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then filed a suit No. 345 of 1952 on the file of the Sub-Judge of Mandi on November 26, 1952  along with certain others in whose names one other liquor licence had been taken and who were evidently similarly situated  for a permanent injunction...

facts.text: The suit was withdrawn on May 12, 1953, with liberty granted under O. 23 rule 1. Civil Procedure Code to file a fresh suit.

anchor.surface_text: Several technical objections were raised to the maintainability of that suit and thereafter the suit was withdrawn on May 12, 1953, with liberty granted under O. 23 rule 1. Civil Procedure Code to file a fresh suit.

facts.text: In pursuance of this liberty the suit out of which the appeal before us arises, was instituted in the Court of the District Judge, Mandi on May 5, 1953, which was substantially one for damages for breach of contract.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this liberty the suit our of which the appeal before us arises, was instituted in the Court of the District Judge, Mandi on May 5, 1953, which was substantially one for damages for breach of companytract.

facts.text: The Union of India against whom the suit was brought, raised several defences... that the suit was bad for want of a proper notice under section 80... and that the suit was barred under the Punjab Land Revenue Act... and the Punjab Excise Act, 1914.

anchor.surface_text: The Union on India against whom the suit was brought, raised several defences both on the merits as well as of a technical nature, the latter being mainly two  1  that the suit was bad for want of a proper numberice under section 80...

facts.text: The learned District Judge upheld the technical objections raised but also recorded his findings on the merits and the findings on most of the items of claim were against the appellant. The appellants suit was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The learned District Judge upheld the technical objections raised but also recorded his findings on the merits and the findings on most of the items of claim were against the appellant. The appellants suit was dismissed.

facts.text: An appeal was thereupon taken by the appellant to the Judicial Commissioner, Himachal Pradesh who substantially agreed with every one of the findings of the learned District Judge both on the technical objections... He further reversed the finding on one of the items of the claim which the trial-Judge had found in appellants favour. The appeal was accordingly dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was thereupon taken by the appellant to the Judicial Commissioner, Himachal Pradesh who substantially agreed with every one of the findings of the learned District Judge both on the technical objections to the suit as well as on the merits...

facts.text: The appellant thereafter applied for a certificate of fitness under Article 133 (1) (b) for preferring an appeal to this Court but the same having been rejected, he applied for and obtained special leave from this Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter applied for a certificate of fitness under Article 133 1  b  for preferring an appeal to this Court but the same having been rejected, he applied for and obtained special leave from this Court...

facts.text: The plaintiff delivered a notice under section 80, Civil Procedure Code containing the requisite particulars to the defendant through the Collector, Mandi on September 4, 1952 and through the Chief Secretary on September 3, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff delivered a numberice under section 80, Civil Procedure Code companytaining the requisite particulars to the defendant through the Collector, Mandi on September 4, 1952 and through the Chief Secretary on September 3, 1952.

facts.text: A previous suit for injunction was withdrawn on May 12, 1953 with permission to bring a fresh suit on payment of costs which was deposited on May 13, 1953 per Challan No. 17 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: A previous suit for injunction was withdrawn on May 12, 1953 with permission to bring a fresh suit on payment of companyts which was deposited on May 13, 1953 per Challan No. 17 of 1953.

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. C. P. Agencies

anchor.surface_text: State of Madras v. C. P. Agencies , in which Das, C.J., speaking for the Court, said The object of section 80 is manifestly to give the Government or the public officer sufficient numberice for the case which is proposed to be brought against it or him so that it or he may companysider the position and decide for itself or himself whether the claim of the plaintiff should be accepted or resisted. In order to enable the Government or the public officer to arrive at a decision it is necessary that it or he should be informed of the nature of the suit proposed to be filed against it or him and the facts on which the claim is founded and the precise reliefs asked for.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v. C. P. Agencies
precedents.cited_proposition: Object of section 80 CPC is to give Government or public officer sufficient notice of the nature of the suit, facts on which claim is founded, and precise reliefs so that it can consider and decide whether to accept or resist the claim
precedents.cited_holding: The object of section 80 is manifestly to give the Government or the public officer sufficient numberice for the case which is proposed to be brought against it or him so that it or he may companysider the position and decide for itself or himself whether the claim of the plaintiff should be accepted or resisted. In order to enable the Government or the public officer to arrive at a decision it is necessary that it or he should be informed of the nature of the suit proposed to be filed against it or him and the facts on which the claim is founded and the precise reliefs asked for.
